An aldosterone test measures the level of aldosterone (a hormone made by the adrenal glands), in the blood. Aldosterone helps regulate sodium and potassium levels in the body.

Why It Is Done. An aldosterone test is done to: 1  Measure the amount of aldosterone released into the body by the adrenal glands. 2  Check for a tumor in the adrenal glands. 3  Find the cause of high blood pressure or low blood potassium levels.

• Aldosterone is produced in the cortex of the adrenal gland, whereas ADH is secreted by the hypothalamus. • Aldosterone is the main regulator of water and electrolytes such as Sodium and Potassium in the body, but ADH is released when water level of the blood stream is lower.

Renin is produced by the kidneys and controls the activation of the hormone angiotensin, which stimulates the adrenal glands to produce aldosterone. The kidneys release renin when there is a drop in blood pressure or a decrease in sodium chloride concentration in the tubules in the kidney.
